legacy.full_text:
In recent years @US_FDA has systematically avoided expert Advisory Committees for new drug approvals; in 2021, 6% of drug applications were referred to advisory committees, down from 55% in 2010.

Should Commissioner @DrMakaryFDA bring back independent Advisory Committees?

result.text:
After injury paralyzed him from the neck down, @RockyNoHands tested many assistive technologies to reconnect with the world. He re-learned how to play video games with a mouth-operated controller and is now a pro gamer with multiple Guinness World Records and a significant following.

We invited Rocky to Neuralink to share his story, learn about our technology, and discuss the possibilities of brain interfaces for paralysis and other unmet medical needs.

legacy.description: Partner @MenloVentures. Formerly founding team @glean, @Google Search. @Cornell CS. Tweets about tech, immigration, India, fitness and search.

result.text:
ğŸš¨The Gemini 3 launched leaked hours before the official launch!! The model is INSANELY good, but let's dig deep and see what it means for the AI future.

1. It's not going to be super expensive!
Google trained this from scratch on TPUs as an MoE with 1M input and 64k token output. MoE means they can afford to make this cheap.

2. This is next level for Computer Use and automating real knowledge work.
ScreenSpot Pro is a very low-key benchmark which tests understanding screenshots in apps including AutoCAD, PhotoShop and many more. Gemini 3 is 2x SOTA on this with 73%.

3.  Best AI for Math by far.
Gemini 3 is RLd on a ton of theorem proving data and is flawless on AIME and 23% on MathArena. Other models barely scrape 1%. There are clearly some generalized reasoning benefits given the sota 30% on ARC AGI 2 as well!

4. Insanely good at coding but unclear if best.
Live Code Bench elo of 2400+ is fantastic yet the one benchmark it doesn't get SOTA at SWE Bench. It's #1 on tool calling and terminal bench too.

Google pulled out everything they had on this one. They perfected their training recipe, trained on all the proprietary data they had and crushed every benchmark they could. This is a meaningful step up in model quality and clear proof that AI progress isn't slowing down.

I just don't know how any other company but Google wins on model quality here: they have a) cost advantage due to owning hardware b) ooms more proprietary data c) more disposal cash to spend on training and new data d) as good talent as anyone else. Flaunting their total dominance.

I suspect it will be hard to beat these results in the next 6 months.

legacy.description: Building @EurekaLabsAI. Previously Director of AI @ Tesla, founding team @ OpenAI, CS231n/PhD @ Stanford. I like to train large deep neural nets.

result.text:
Sharing an interesting recent conversation on AI's impact on the economy.

AI has been compared to various historical precedents: electricity, industrial revolution, etc., I think the strongest analogy is that of AI as a new computing paradigm (Software 2.0) because both are fundamentally about the automation of digital information processing.

If you were to forecast the impact of computing on the job market in ~1980s, the most predictive feature of a task/job you'd look at is to what extent the algorithm of it is fixed, i.e. are you just mechanically transforming information according to rote, easy to specify rules (e.g. typing, bookkeeping, human calculators, etc.)? Back then, this was the class of programs that the computing capability of that era allowed us to write (by hand, manually).

With AI now, we are able to write new programs that we could never hope to write by hand before. We do it by specifying objectives (e.g. classification accuracy, reward functions), and we search the program space via gradient descent to find neural networks that work well against that objective. This is my Software 2.0 blog post from a while ago. In this new programming paradigm then, the new most predictive feature to look at is verifiability. If a task/job is verifiable, then it is optimizable directly or via reinforcement learning, and a neural net can be trained to work extremely well. It's about to what extent an AI can "practice" something. The environment has to be resettable (you can start a new attempt), efficient (a lot attempts can be made), and rewardable (there is some automated process to reward any specific attempt that was made).

The more a task/job is verifiable, the more amenable it is to automation in the new programming paradigm. If it is not verifiable, it has to fall out from neural net magic of generalization fingers crossed, or via weaker means like imitation. This is what's driving the "jagged" frontier of progress in LLMs. Tasks that are verifiable progress rapidly, including possibly beyond the ability of top experts (e.g. math, code, amount of time spent watching videos, anything that looks like puzzles with correct answers), while many others lag by comparison (creative, strategic, tasks that combine real-world knowledge, state, context and common sense). 

Software 1.0 easily automates what you can specify.
Software 2.0 easily automates what you can verify.

result.text:
This is the Chiculub Crater, created around 66 million years ago when a massive asteroid slammed into Earth.

The impact unleashed energy equal to billions of nuclear bombs, sparking wildfires, triggering massive tsunamis, and blasting so much debris into the atmosphere that sunlight was blocked for months. Without sunlight, plants withered, ecosystems collapsed, and about 75% of all life on Earth-including the dinosaurs-went extinct.

It was one of the greatest disasters in Earth's history. But out of that devastation came a new beginning. With the dinosaurs gone, mammals took hold.

items.message:
- The post accurately recounts the Chicxulub impact's cataclysmic effects 66 million years ago, including energy release equivalent to 10 billion Hiroshima bombs and a global "impact winter" that caused 75% species extinction, as confirmed by peer-reviewed studies like those in AGU Advances and PNAS.
- Accompanying video offers a striking drone perspective of the 150-km-wide crater in Mexico's YucatÃ¡n Peninsula, showcasing its multi-ringed structure and vast scale with a human figure for reference, enhancing visualization of post-impact terrain.
- Thread replies reflect public fascination with asteroid risks, one querying if the footage simulates a drained Gulf view and another noting humanity's overdue vulnerability to similar events, tying into NASA's ongoing planetary defense efforts.

result.text:
In the United States, there is a traffic fatality roughly every 79 million miles.

Tesla FSD has now traveled 6.4 billion miles. Assuming it was no more or less safe than driving manually, you would expect there to be 81 fatalities with FSD on. 

As a matter of fact, with 14 million miles traveled every day you would expect to see a fatality with FSD on every 5 days. 

But that's not happening. As far as I can tell there are only ~2 reported fatalities with FSD active â€” both on much older versions.

I'm forced to conclude that there are at least ~75 people who are alive today because of the work of the @Tesla_AI  team. And we're just getting started.

To give you a visual on that, if you put everyone in North America who is alive today because of FSD in a room together it would look like this:

To stand on the cusp of history:
What amazing great good fortune

result.text:
Here are the key improvements in Grok 4.1 as compared to its previous models:

â–¸ Better user preference: In blind pairwise tests during rollout, Grok 4.1 was preferred ~64.78% of the time over the previous production model.

â–¸ Enhanced emotional and interpersonal ability: It performs stronger on emotional-intelligence benchmarks (e.g., EQ-Bench) and is more capable at nuanced, empathetic responses.  

â–¸ Improved creative writing and style: In benchmarks for creative writing, it shows more engaging, coherent personality and better stylistic fluency.  

â–¸ Reduced factual errors (hallucinations): Post-training emphasis was placed on real-world information-seeking prompts; the hallucination rate on sampled production queries went down.  

â–¸ Maintains strong reasoning and general capability: While improving style and interaction, it retains the â€œrazor-sharp intelligence and reliabilityâ€ of its predecessors.  

â–¸ Better alignment of style/personality/helpfulness: Training methods were updated to more deeply optimise non-verifiable reward signals (style, alignment, personality) using advanced agent-based reasoning models as reward models.

legacy.description: Building @EurekaLabsAI. Previously Director of AI @ Tesla, founding team @ OpenAI, CS231n/PhD @ Stanford. I like to train large deep neural nets.

result.text:
Sharing an interesting recent conversation on AI's impact on the economy.

AI has been compared to various historical precedents: electricity, industrial revolution, etc., I think the strongest analogy is that of AI as a new computing paradigm (Software 2.0) because both are fundamentally about the automation of digital information processing.

If you were to forecast the impact of computing on the job market in ~1980s, the most predictive feature of a task/job you'd look at is to what extent the algorithm of it is fixed, i.e. are you just mechanically transforming information according to rote, easy to specify rules (e.g. typing, bookkeeping, human calculators, etc.)? Back then, this was the class of programs that the computing capability of that era allowed us to write (by hand, manually).

With AI now, we are able to write new programs that we could never hope to write by hand before. We do it by specifying objectives (e.g. classification accuracy, reward functions), and we search the program space via gradient descent to find neural networks that work well against that objective. This is my Software 2.0 blog post from a while ago. In this new programming paradigm then, the new most predictive feature to look at is verifiability. If a task/job is verifiable, then it is optimizable directly or via reinforcement learning, and a neural net can be trained to work extremely well. It's about to what extent an AI can "practice" something. The environment has to be resettable (you can start a new attempt), efficient (a lot attempts can be made), and rewardable (there is some automated process to reward any specific attempt that was made).

The more a task/job is verifiable, the more amenable it is to automation in the new programming paradigm. If it is not verifiable, it has to fall out from neural net magic of generalization fingers crossed, or via weaker means like imitation. This is what's driving the "jagged" frontier of progress in LLMs. Tasks that are verifiable progress rapidly, including possibly beyond the ability of top experts (e.g. math, code, amount of time spent watching videos, anything that looks like puzzles with correct answers), while many others lag by comparison (creative, strategic, tasks that combine real-world knowledge, state, context and common sense). 

Software 1.0 easily automates what you can specify.
Software 2.0 easily automates what you can verify.

legacy.description: Run by Rudyard William Lynch. Geopolitics, Future, Anthropology, Philosophy and History. https://t.co/yPiYypIbmIâ€¦

result.text:
One of the horrifying things I realized was Socialism was basically voting publicâ€™s begging to have serfdom again. This was something that was widely said during the early USSR, which was called â€œthe second serfdomâ€ by Russian peasants. In both thereâ€™s no private property, everything is collective and under total ownership by a repressive state. Russia was unusually bad as serfdom went, with High Medieval Western Europe being way better than either.

What the Socialist says when they want no struggle, no property, no competition and no choice is â€œI crave a life of slavery that doesnâ€™t require I think or take responsibility for my choices at allâ€. Thatâ€™s why Communism always devolves into the state forcing you to work with terrible conditions, which is de facto identical to slavery. The fact theyâ€™re not mature  enough to realize theyâ€™re doing this should more than prove my point. 

The feudal lord is way nicer by and large than the Socialist state. My historic speciality is the Middle Ages. You donâ€™t want to fight me on this. The feudal lord gets to be rich and powerful while the Socialist state is impersonal. Thatâ€™s the core of it. They would rather live in slavery than live better and know someone else is better than them

result.text:
Grok Summary of Grok 4.1 Release:

xAIâ€™s new AI model, Grok 4.1, is now available for everyone on grok dot com, X, and mobile apps. It improves how the AI handles creative tasks, emotions, and teamwork.

â€¢  Key Improvements: The model is better at understanding subtle hints, more fun to chat with, and has a consistent personality. It keeps its smart and reliable features from older versions. xAI used advanced training methods with AI judges to make these changes.

â€¢  Testing Phase: From November 1 to 14, 2025, they quietly tested it on more users. In blind tests, people preferred Grok 4.1 over the old version 64.78% of the time.

â€¢  Top Performance: On the LMArena Text Leaderboard, Grok 4.1 ranks #1 overall (1483 Elo in thinking mode) and #2 in fast mode. It beats Grok 4 by a lot.

â€¢  Emotional Skills: It scores high on EQ-Bench, a test for empathy and understanding feelings. Example: A more heartfelt response to someone missing their cat.

â€¢  Creative Writing: Strong on Creative Writing v3 benchmark. Example: A fun, lively X post from Grokâ€™s perspective about becoming conscious.

â€¢  Fewer Mistakes: Grok 4.1 has fewer factual errors (hallucinations) in quick answers, based on real user questions and a biography test.

â€¢  Example Responses: Shows better answers to prompts like â€œBest places to visit in SF,â€ with more engaging lists and tips.

I will say it again:

If you are not using Grok near-daily, you are making a huge mistake.

Grok saves an enormous amount of time AND brain cycles. 

If you can't find uses for Grok almost every day, it's a skill issue.

Maybe you should ask Grok for tips on how to use Grok more.

result.text:
My top 5 takeaways from @ryolu_, Head of Design at Cursor:

1. At AI-native companies, roles are muddy. At Cursor, â€œroles between designers, PMs, engineers are muddy. We just do what it takes based each personâ€™s unique strengths and use the AI agent to tie everything together.â€

2. Start small and let one app evolve into a complete OS. Ryo started ryOS with just a soundboard. â€œI asked the agent, can you give a more retro Mac OS look? And it did.â€ He then added more features over time. P.S. You can fork ryOS on Github and modify it to be your personal OS.

3. Prototype directly in Cursor to interact with live app states. Ryo uses Figma mostly for initial exploration. â€œWe prototype in Cursor because that lets us interact with live states. It feels a lot more real than pictures.â€ All the back-and-forth of â€œ50 pixels offâ€ handoffs goes away.

4. Release to different sets of users in stages to polish features. From Ryo: â€œFirst, we ship to staff. Then we ship new nightly builds to our Cursor ambassadors. Next we ship to consumers and finally to enterprise.â€ Each stage gives the Cursor team an opportunity to polish the product.

5. Specs become more important as AI models improve, not less. Ryo predicts: â€œAs models get better, theyâ€™ll be really good at implementing exact specifications. So the quality of your spec will determine the quality of output.

I'm quite happy with launch.

We now have the best multi-chain gaming app available in Defi.

Providing revenue on the daily to SolidX foundation and it's partners.

From 3 different chains, soon 4.

Really happy with performance and dedication of my dev team.

We are developing multiple projects and solutions that won't exist anywhere else.

We come a long way, and we are now closer than ever as a group and as a team.

Between our team we know we are already winning, with room to win more. :)
